posts.name: Matt Soucy (he/him)
posts.cooked: FRC Team 166, the Chop Shop, is excited to announce the return of our Code Review Party! After a long hiatus due to the 2020 Interruption, we're leveraging this opportunity to foster collaboration among teams by having them review each other's code. This bidirectional approach encourages mutual learning, helping teams improve their software development skills. By participating, teams will receive valuable feedback, ensuring they can grow from both their successes and areas needing improvement. Teams interested in joining can sign up by filling out the form [here](https://forms.gle/8rJsH8EqWfmMMBB58). The Code Review Party operates under specific rules: teams will have until June 28, 2025, to sign up, and reviews must be submitted by August 30, 2025. Once enough teams are registered, each may receive feedback from multiple peers. Feedback must be constructive and avoid suggesting alternative programming languages, as teams already have reasons for choosing their current tools. To facilitate effective communication, reviews should be conducted through repository issues, starting with a central issue and using checklists for minor comments, linking related issues for significant feedback. By participating, you commit to sharing your code and reviewing others', contributing to a richer learning environment for everyone.

link_counts.title: Change one letter of a thread title

posts.name: Jimmy McCosker
posts.cooked: Registration will be open until 6/28/2020 oh looks like we’ve missed it

posts.name: Matt Soucy (he/him)
posts.cooked: This is what I get for starting with the 2020 CRP’s post. Nice catch! Dates are fixed to be 2025.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: This sounds great. I need to get in touch with my students to determine who will serve as a designated reviewer. If someone doesn't sign up, can they still review? Otherwise, I will put myself as a reviewer and see who I can get by June to do the review.

posts.name: Ben
posts.cooked: Would teams that use specific languages only be partnered with other teams using the same language? For example, if I only know Java, would I still receive C++ and LabVIEW repositories, or would I only receive Java ones?

posts.name: Matt Soucy (he/him)
posts.cooked: Yes teams will be partnered with other teams based on the language of their code. Based on FIRST’s reported language use most teams will probably be using Java but I’ll check each submission just to be safe.

posts.name: Matt Soucy (he/him)
posts.cooked: Any number of team members can review code, even if they don't sign up on the form—the reviewer list ensures there's a point of contact. If there are more than three reviewers, though, please don't submit the form again so you can list them all.
Are FTC teams also welcome to join the party? Would love to get feedback on our code.

posts.name: Matt Soucy (he/him)
posts.cooked: The article discusses concerns regarding potential discrepancies in code structure between FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) and FIRST Tech Challenge (FTC) teams within the WPIlib framework. Due to the current lack of competition unification, FTC teams may receive feedback primarily oriented towards FRC, potentially complicating the integration process. To mitigate this, the author proposes pairing FTC teams whenever multiple registrations occur, ensuring smoother collaboration despite the ongoing separation.
Is your profile picture a Lego Perry the Platypus? Nice! Thanks I got bored while mentoring one of my FLL teams

posts.name: Matt Soucy (he/him)
posts.cooked: We currently have thirteen teams signed up! Almost all of them use Java as their language, although there’s some additional Kotlin and Python. Registration is still open until 6/28/2025 (I got the date right this time!), so there’s time to join in!

posts.name: Matt Soucy (he/him)
posts.cooked: The original text mentions that there are sixteen teams and that sign-ups will close in eight days.

posts.name: Itay Kaufman
posts.cooked: Y Herm

posts.name: Matt Soucy (he/him)
posts.cooked: The submission form is now closed! I will be assigning teams within the next few days.

posts.name: Matt Soucy (he/him)
posts.cooked: I am sending out the assignments now from a mcrbnh.com email address. If you don’t receive one in the next few days, check your spam folder and send a message here.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: Any suggestions on format? Just creating a document? Using Github issues?

posts.name: Matt Soucy (he/him)
posts.cooked: GitHub issues are preferred

posts.cooked: I think it would be fun to read some code, even if I'm not participating. Would any teams be interested in posting links to their own code in this thread?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: the field reset life chose me (6201M, 3419A)

posts.name: Kabir
posts.cooked: You can just make a copy of the linked Google Sheet here, sort randomly (Data → Randomize range), and then go down the list. I scraped GitHub to get all public robot code repos. I decided to search all the repos myself: [2025 repos - Google Sheets](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1qJ__HktxZtAjML0PNV_HYdK8PrBqn3DPkElUYziOSnw/edit?gid=0#gid=0). Instead of individually searching for each team, I just used the code search API to find all the repos at once (splitting the searches by digits in order to not hit the GitHub limit of 1000 results per search). There are a few inaccuracies due to stuff like copied example projects.

link_counts.title: I scraped github to get all public robot code repos

posts.cooked: Yeah, here's the link to our GitHub: GitHub - FRC-7525/Reefscape-7917. We were going to participate in the review party but didn't sign up in time.
